Q: What is the capital of Mexico?
A: Mexico City is the capital of Mexico, one of the largest cities in the world.

Q: What is sound?
A: Sound is a vibration that travels through air or other media as an audible wave.

Q: What is the Pyramids of Giza?
A: The Pyramids of Giza are ancient Egyptian pyramids near Cairo.

Q: Who was Leonardo da Vinci?
A: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian Renaissance artist and inventor.

Q: What is the capital of Canada?
A: Ottawa is the capital of Canada, located in Ontario.

Q: What is Jupiter?
A: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, a gas giant.

Q: What is the Grand Canyon?
A: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River.

Q: Who was Alexander the Great?
A: Alexander the Great was a Macedonian king who created one of the largest empires.

Q: What is the capital of Austria?
A: Vienna is the capital of Austria, located on the Danube River.

Q: Who was Abraham Lincoln?
A: Abraham Lincoln was the 16th President of the United States.

Q: What is photosynthesis?
A: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy.

Q: What is the Atlantic Ocean?
A: The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the Statue of Liberty?
A: The Statue of Liberty is a copper statue in New York Harbor.

Q: Who was Ludwig Beethoven?
A: Ludwig Beethoven was a German composer who bridged Classical and Romantic eras.

Q: What is electricity?
A: Electricity is the flow of electric charge through a conductor.

Q: What is copper?
A: Copper is a chemical element with symbol Cu and atomic number 29, an excellent conductor.

Q: What is the capital of Czech Republic?
A: Prague is the capital of Czech Republic, known as the City of a Hundred Spires.

Q: Who was Franklin Roosevelt?
A: Franklin D. Roosevelt was the 32nd President of the United States.

Q: Who was Albert Einstein?
A: Albert Einstein was a German-born physicist who developed the theory of relativity.

Q: What is Asia?
A: Asia is the largest and most populous continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Portugal?
A: Lisbon is the capital of Portugal, located on the Atlantic coast.

Q: Who was Pablo Picasso?
A: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter and sculptor who co-founded Cubism.

Q: What is silver?
A: Silver is a chemical element with symbol Ag and atomic number 47, used in jewelry and coins.

Q: What is the Taj Mahal?
A: The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum in Agra, India.

Q: What is the Sahara Desert?
A: The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.

Q: What is gold?
A: Gold is a chemical element with symbol Au and atomic number 79, a precious metal.

Q: What is the capital of Malaysia?
A: Kuala Lumpur is the capital of Malaysia, known for its modern skyline.

Q: Who was Jesus Christ?
A: Jesus Christ was the central figure of Christianity.

Q: What is carbon?
A: Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, the basis of organic chemistry.

Q: Who was William Shakespeare?
A: William Shakespeare was an English playwright and poet.

Q: What is the capital of Turkey?
A: Ankara is the capital of Turkey, though Istanbul is the largest city.

Q: What is respiration?
A: Respiration is the process of exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Q: Who was Galileo Galilei?
A: Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer who supported the heliocentric model.

Q: What is North America?
A: North America is the third-largest continent by area.

Q: What is evolution?
A: Evolution is the process of change in species over generations.

Q: What is the capital of Singapore?
A: Singapore is the capital of Singapore, a city-state in Southeast Asia.

Q: What is temperature?
A: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles.

Q: Who was Nelson Mandela?
A: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and president.

Q: What is the capital of Thailand?
A: Bangkok is the capital of Thailand, known as the City of Angels.

Q: What is the Arctic?
A: The Arctic is the polar region around Earth's North Pole.

Q: What is the capital of Australia?
A: Canberra is the capital of Australia, located between Sydney and Melbourne.

Q: What is the Colosseum?
A: The Colosseum is an ancient Roman amphitheater in Rome.

Q: What is the capital of Netherlands?
A: Amsterdam is the capital of Netherlands, known for its canals.

Q: What is an atom?
A: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.

Q: Who was Thomas Edison?
A: Thomas Edison was an American inventor who created the light bulb.

Q: What is the Moon?
A: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite, orbiting at about 384,400 kilometers.

Q: What is RNA?
A: RNA is ribonucleic acid, essential for protein synthesis.

Q: Who was Isaac Newton?
A: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician and physicist who discovered gravity.

Q: Who was Julius Caesar?
A: Julius Caesar was a Roman general and statesman.

Q: Who was Cleopatra?
A: Cleopatra was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.

Q: Who was Henry Ford?
A: Henry Ford was an American industrialist who founded Ford Motor Company.

Q: What is the capital of Norway?
A: Oslo is the capital of Norway, located at the head of a fjord.

Q: What is the capital of Brazil?
A: Brasilia is the capital of Brazil, a planned city built in the 1960s.

Q: Who was Nikola Tesla?
A: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who developed AC electricity.

Q: Who was Plato?
A: Plato was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of the Academy.

Q: What is the Mississippi?
A: The Mississippi is the second-longest river in North America.

Q: Who was Martin Luther King Jr.?
A: Martin Luther King Jr. was an American civil rights leader.

Q: What is the capital of New Zealand?
A: Wellington is the capital of New Zealand, the southernmost capital in the world.

Q: Who was the Wright Brothers?
A: The Wright Brothers were American aviation pioneers who invented the airplane.

Q: What is the capital of Spain?
A: Madrid is the capital of Spain, located in the center of the country.

Q: What is the capital of Japan?
A: Tokyo is the capital of Japan, one of the most populous cities in the world.

Q: What is the Pacific Ocean?
A: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Finland?
A: Helsinki is the capital of Finland, located on the Gulf of Finland.

Q: What is Earth?
A: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known planet with life.

Q: Who was Charles Darwin?
A: Charles Darwin was an English naturalist who developed the theory of evolution.

Q: Who was Queen Victoria?
A: Queen Victoria ruled the United Kingdom from 1837 to 1901.

Q: What is the Amazon?
A: The Amazon is the largest river by volume, flowing through South America.

Q: Who was Queen Elizabeth II?
A: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning British monarch.

Q: What is water?
A: Water is a chemical compound with the formula H2O, essential for all known forms of life.

Q: Who was Napoleon Bonaparte?
A: Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military leader who became Emperor.

Q: What is the capital of Switzerland?
A: Bern is the capital of Switzerland, though Zurich is the largest city.

Q: What is the capital of Egypt?
A: Cairo is the capital of Egypt, located on the Nile River.

Q: What is pressure?
A: Pressure is force applied perpendicular to a surface per unit area.

Q: Who was Confucius?
A: Confucius was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings influenced East Asian culture.

Q: What is the capital of Sweden?
A: Stockholm is the capital of Sweden, built on 14 islands.

Q: What is the capital of India?
A: New Delhi is the capital of India, located in northern India.

Q: What is Antarctica?
A: Antarctica is the coldest and driest continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of France?
A: Paris is the capital of France, located on the Seine River.

Q: What is the capital of Ukraine?
A: Kyiv is the capital of Ukraine, located on the Dnieper River.

Q: What is hydrogen?
A: Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1, the lightest element.

Q: What is Saturn?
A: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, famous for its ring system.

Q: Who was Socrates?
A: Socrates was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of Western philosophy.

Q: Who was George Washington?
A: George Washington was the first President of the United States.

Q: What is Mars?
A: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet.

Q: What is the capital of Philippines?
A: Manila is the capital of Philippines, located on Luzon island.

Q: What is the Sun?
A: The Sun is a star at the center of the Solar System, providing light and heat to Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Italy?
A: Rome is the capital of Italy, known as the Eternal City.

Q: What is the capital of Ireland?
A: Dublin is the capital of Ireland, located on the east coast.

Q: Who was Mahatma Gandhi?
A: Mahatma Gandhi was the leader of Indian independence movement.

Q: Who was Winston Churchill?
A: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during World War II.

Q: What is Africa?
A: Africa is the second-largest and second-most populous continent.

Q: What is the capital of South Korea?
A: Seoul is the capital of South Korea, one of the largest metropolitan areas.

Q: Who was Benjamin Franklin?
A: Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath and Founding Father.

Q: What is the capital of Russia?
A: Moscow is the capital of Russia, the largest city in Europe.

Q: What is a molecule?
A: A molecule is a group of atoms bonded together.

Q: What is Europe?
A: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere.

Q: Who was Michelangelo?
A: Michelangelo was an Italian sculptor and painter of the Renaissance.

Q: What is the capital of Vietnam?
A: Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam, located in northern Vietnam.

Q: Who was Wolfgang Mozart?
A: Wolfgang Mozart was an Austrian composer of classical music.

Q: What is Australia?
A: Australia is a country and continent in the Southern Hemisphere.

Q: What is oxygen?
A: Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8, essential for respiration.

Q: Who was Marie Curie?
A: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist who discovered radioactivity.

Q: Who was Aristotle?
A: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist.

Q: What is the capital of Denmark?
A: Copenhagen is the capital of Denmark, located on the islands of Zealand and Amager.

Q: Who was Buddha?
A: Buddha was the founder of Buddhism, born as Siddhartha Gautama.

Q: What is the capital of Poland?
A: Warsaw is the capital of Poland, located on the Vistula River.

Q: What is a cell?
A: A cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

Q: What is the capital of Greece?
A: Athens is the capital of Greece, one of the oldest cities in the world.

Q: What is the capital of Belgium?
A: Brussels is the capital of Belgium, the de facto capital of the European Union.

Q: What is iron?
A: Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26, essential for blood.

Q: Who was Johann Bach?
A: Johann Sebastian Bach was a German composer of the Baroque period.

Q: What is Mount Everest?
A: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth at 8,849 meters.

Q: What is the capital of Indonesia?
A: Jakarta is the capital of Indonesia, located on the island of Java.

Q: What is the capital of China?
A: Beijing is the capital of China, located in northern China.

Q: Who was Vincent van Gogh?
A: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter.

Q: What is South America?
A: South America is a continent in the Western Hemisphere.

Q: What is the Great Wall of China?
A: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications spanning thousands of kilometers.

Q: What is DNA?
A: DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information.

Q: What is the capital of Germany?
A: Berlin is the capital of Germany, the largest city in Germany.

Q: Who was Thomas Jefferson?
A: Thomas Jefferson was the third President and author of the Declaration of Independence.

Q: Who was Muhammad?
A: Muhammad was the founder of Islam and its prophet.

Q: What is magnetism?
A: Magnetism is a force produced by moving electric charges.

Q: What is the capital of Argentina?
A: Buenos Aires is the capital of Argentina, located on the Rio de la Plata.

Q: What is the Eiffel Tower?
A: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower in Paris, France.

Q: What is nitrogen?
A: Nitrogen is a chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7, making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

Q: What is the capital of South Africa?
A: Pretoria is the capital of South Africa, the administrative capital.

Q: What is the Nile?
A: The Nile is the longest river in Africa, flowing through Egypt.

Q: What is the capital of Romania?
A: Bucharest is the capital of Romania, the largest city in Romania.

Q: What is the capital of Hungary?
A: Budapest is the capital of Hungary, formed by uniting Buda and Pest.

Q: What is gravity?
A: Gravity is a force that attracts objects with mass toward each other.

Q: What is light?
A: Light is electromagnetic radiation visible to the human eye.

A: Kuala Lumpur is the capital of Malaysia, known for its modern skyline.

Q: Who was Jesus Christ?
A: Jesus Christ was the central figure of Christianity.

Q: What is carbon?
A: Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, the basis of organic chemistry.

Q: Who was William Shakespeare?
A: William Shakespeare was an English playwright and poet.

Q: What is the capital of Turkey?
A: Ankara is the capital of Turkey, though Istanbul is the largest city.

Q: What is respiration?
A: Respiration is the process of exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Q: Who was Galileo Galilei?
A: Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer who supported the heliocentric model.

Q: What is North America?
A: North America is the third-largest continent by area.

Q: What is evolution?
A: Evolution is the process of change in species over generations.

Q: What is the capital of Singapore?
A: Singapore is the capital of Singapore, a city-state in Southeast Asia.

Q: What is temperature?
A: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles.

Q: Who was Nelson Mandela?
A: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and president.

Q: What is the capital of Thailand?
A: Bangkok is the capital of Thailand, known as the City of Angels.

Q: What is the Arctic?
A: The Arctic is the polar region around Earth's North Pole.

Q: What is the capital of Australia?
A: Canberra is the capital of Australia, located between Sydney and Melbourne.

Q: What is the Colosseum?
A: The Colosseum is an ancient Roman amphitheater in Rome.

Q: What is the capital of Netherlands?
A: Amsterdam is the capital of Netherlands, known for its canals.

Q: What is an atom?
A: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.

Q: Who was Thomas Edison?
A: Thomas Edison was an American inventor who created the light bulb.

Q: What is the Moon?
A: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite, orbiting at about 384,400 kilometers.

Q: What is RNA?
A: RNA is ribonucleic acid, essential for protein synthesis.

Q: Who was Isaac Newton?
A: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician and physicist who discovered gravity.

Q: Who was Julius Caesar?
A: Julius Caesar was a Roman general and statesman.

Q: Who was Cleopatra?
A: Cleopatra was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.

Q: Who was Henry Ford?
A: Henry Ford was an American industrialist who founded Ford Motor Company.

Q: What is the capital of Norway?
A: Oslo is the capital of Norway, located at the head of a fjord.

Q: What is the capital of Brazil?
A: Brasilia is the capital of Brazil, a planned city built in the 1960s.

Q: Who was Nikola Tesla?
A: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who developed AC electricity.

Q: Who was Plato?
A: Plato was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of the Academy.

Q: What is the Mississippi?
A: The Mississippi is the second-longest river in North America.

Q: Who was Martin Luther King Jr.?
A: Martin Luther King Jr. was an American civil rights leader.

Q: What is the capital of New Zealand?
A: Wellington is the capital of New Zealand, the southernmost capital in the world.

Q: Who was the Wright Brothers?
A: The Wright Brothers were American aviation pioneers who invented the airplane.

Q: What is the capital of Spain?
A: Madrid is the capital of Spain, located in the center of the country.

Q: What is the capital of Japan?
A: Tokyo is the capital of Japan, one of the most populous cities in the world.

Q: What is the Pacific Ocean?
A: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Finland?
A: Helsinki is the capital of Finland, located on the Gulf of Finland.

Q: What is Earth?
A: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known planet with life.

Q: Who was Charles Darwin?
A: Charles Darwin was an English naturalist who developed the theory of evolution.

Q: Who was Queen Victoria?
A: Queen Victoria ruled the United Kingdom from 1837 to 1901.

Q: What is the Amazon?
A: The Amazon is the largest river by volume, flowing through South America.

Q: Who was Queen Elizabeth II?
A: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning British monarch.

Q: What is water?
A: Water is a chemical compound with the formula H2O, essential for all known forms of life.

Q: Who was Napoleon Bonaparte?
A: Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military leader who became Emperor.

Q: What is the capital of Switzerland?
A: Bern is the capital of Switzerland, though Zurich is the largest city.

Q: What is the capital of Egypt?
A: Cairo is the capital of Egypt, located on the Nile River.

Q: What is pressure?
A: Pressure is force applied perpendicular to a surface per unit area.

Q: Who was Confucius?
A: Confucius was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings influenced East Asian culture.

Q: What is the capital of Sweden?
A: Stockholm is the capital of Sweden, built on 14 islands.

Q: What is the capital of India?
A: New Delhi is the capital of India, located in northern India.

Q: What is Antarctica?
A: Antarctica is the coldest and driest continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of France?
A: Paris is the capital of France, located on the Seine River.

Q: What is the capital of Ukraine?
A: Kyiv is the capital of Ukraine, located on the Dnieper River.

Q: What is hydrogen?
A: Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1, the lightest element.

Q: What is Saturn?
A: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, famous for its ring system.

Q: Who was Socrates?
A: Socrates was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of Western philosophy.

Q: Who was George Washington?
A: George Washington was the first President of the United States.

Q: What is Mars?
A: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet.

Q: What is the capital of Philippines?
A: Manila is the capital of Philippines, located on Luzon island.

Q: What is the Sun?
A: The Sun is a star at the center of the Solar System, providing light and heat to Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Italy?
A: Rome is the capital of Italy, known as the Eternal City.

Q: What is the capital of Ireland?
A: Dublin is the capital of Ireland, located on the east coast.

Q: Who was Mahatma Gandhi?
A: Mahatma Gandhi was the leader of Indian independence movement.

Q: Who was Winston Churchill?
A: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during World War II.

Q: What is Africa?
A: Africa is the second-largest and second-most populous continent.

Q: What is the capital of South Korea?
A: Seoul is the capital of South Korea, one of the largest metropolitan areas.

Q: Who was Benjamin Franklin?
A: Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath and Founding Father.

Q: What is the capital of Russia?
A: Moscow is the capital of Russia, the largest city in Europe.

Q: What is a molecule?
A: A molecule is a group of atoms bonded together.

Q: What is Europe?
A: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere.

Q: Who was Michelangelo?
A: Michelangelo was an Italian sculptor and painter of the Renaissance.

Q: What is the capital of Vietnam?
A: Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam, located in northern Vietnam.

Q: Who was Wolfgang Mozart?
A: Wolfgang Mozart was an Austrian composer of classical music.

Q: What is Australia?
A: Australia is a country and continent in the Southern Hemisphere.

Q: What is oxygen?
A: Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8, essential for respiration.

Q: Who was Marie Curie?
A: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist who discovered radioactivity.

Q: Who was Aristotle?
A: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist.

Q: What is the capital of Denmark?
A: Copenhagen is the capital of Denmark, located on the islands of Zealand and Amager.

Q: Who was Buddha?
A: Buddha was the founder of Buddhism, born as Siddhartha Gautama.

Q: What is the capital of Poland?
A: Warsaw is the capital of Poland, located on the Vistula River.

Q: What is a cell?
A: A cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

Q: What is the capital of Greece?
A: Athens is the capital of Greece, one of the oldest cities in the world.

Q: What is the capital of Belgium?
A: Brussels is the capital of Belgium, the de facto capital of the European Union.

Q: What is iron?
A: Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26, essential for blood.

Q: Who was Johann Bach?
A: Johann Sebastian Bach was a German composer of the Baroque period.

Q: What is Mount Everest?
A: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth at 8,849 meters.

Q: What is the capital of Indonesia?
A: Jakarta is the capital of Indonesia, located on the island of Java.

Q: What is the capital of China?
A: Beijing is the capital of China, located in northern China.

Q: Who was Vincent van Gogh?
A: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter.

Q: What is South America?
A: South America is a continent in the Western Hemisphere.

Q: What is the Great Wall of China?
A: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications spanning thousands of kilometers.

Q: What is DNA?
A: DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information.

Q: What is the capital of Germany?
A: Berlin is the capital of Germany, the largest city in Germany.

Q: Who was Thomas Jefferson?
A: Thomas Jefferson was the third President and author of the Declaration of Independence.

Q: Who was Muhammad?
A: Muhammad was the founder of Islam and its prophet.

Q: What is magnetism?
A: Magnetism is a force produced by moving electric charges.

Q: What is the capital of Argentina?
A: Buenos Aires is the capital of Argentina, located on the Rio de la Plata.

Q: What is the Eiffel Tower?
A: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower in Paris, France.

Q: What is nitrogen?
A: Nitrogen is a chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7, making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

Q: What is the capital of South Africa?
A: Pretoria is the capital of South Africa, the administrative capital.

Q: What is the Nile?
A: The Nile is the longest river in Africa, flowing through Egypt.

Q: What is the capital of Romania?
A: Bucharest is the capital of Romania, the largest city in Romania.

Q: What is the capital of Hungary?
A: Budapest is the capital of Hungary, formed by uniting Buda and Pest.

Q: What is gravity?
A: Gravity is a force that attracts objects with mass toward each other.

Q: What is light?
A: Light is electromagnetic radiation visible to the human eye.

Q: Who was Alexander Graham Bell?
A: Alexander Graham Bell was the inventor of the telephone.

Q: What is the capital of Mexico?
A: Mexico City is the capital of Mexico, one of the largest cities in the world.

Q: What is sound?
A: Sound is a vibration that travels through air or other media as an audible wave.

Q: What is the Pyramids of Giza?
A: The Pyramids of Giza are ancient Egyptian pyramids near Cairo.

Q: Who was Leonardo da Vinci?
A: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian Renaissance artist and inventor.

Q: What is the capital of Canada?
A: Ottawa is the capital of Canada, located in Ontario.

Q: What is Jupiter?
A: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, a gas giant.

Q: What is the Grand Canyon?
A: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River.

Q: Who was Alexander the Great?
A: Alexander the Great was a Macedonian king who created one of the largest empires.

Q: What is the capital of Austria?
A: Vienna is the capital of Austria, located on the Danube River.

Q: Who was Abraham Lincoln?
A: Abraham Lincoln was the 16th President of the United States.

Q: What is photosynthesis?
A: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy.

Q: What is the Atlantic Ocean?
A: The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the Statue of Liberty?
A: The Statue of Liberty is a copper statue in New York Harbor.

Q: Who was Ludwig Beethoven?
A: Ludwig Beethoven was a German composer who bridged Classical and Romantic eras.

Q: What is electricity?
A: Electricity is the flow of electric charge through a conductor.

Q: What is copper?
A: Copper is a chemical element with symbol Cu and atomic number 29, an excellent conductor.

Q: What is the capital of Czech Republic?
A: Prague is the capital of Czech Republic, known as the City of a Hundred Spires.

A: Franklin D. Roosevelt was the 32nd President of the United States.

A: Albert Einstein was a German-born physicist who developed the theory of relativity.

A: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who developed AC electricity.

Q: Who was Plato?
A: Plato was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of the Academy.

Q: What is the Mississippi?
A: The Mississippi is the second-longest river in North America.

Q: Who was Martin Luther King Jr.?
A: Martin Luther King Jr. was an American civil rights leader.

Q: What is the capital of New Zealand?
A: Wellington is the capital of New Zealand, the southernmost capital in the world.

Q: Who was the Wright Brothers?
A: The Wright Brothers were American aviation pioneers who invented the airplane.

Q: What is the capital of Spain?
A: Madrid is the capital of Spain, located in the center of the country.

Q: What is the capital of Japan?
A: Tokyo is the capital of Japan, one of the most populous cities in the world.

Q: What is the Pacific Ocean?
A: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Finland?
A: Helsinki is the capital of Finland, located on the Gulf of Finland.

Q: What is Earth?
A: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known planet with life.

Q: Who was Charles Darwin?
A: Charles Darwin was an English naturalist who developed the theory of evolution.

Q: Who was Queen Victoria?
A: Queen Victoria ruled the United Kingdom from 1837 to 1901.

Q: What is the Amazon?
A: The Amazon is the largest river by volume, flowing through South America.

Q: Who was Queen Elizabeth II?
A: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning British monarch.

Q: What is water?
A: Water is a chemical compound with the formula H2O, essential for all known forms of life.

Q: Who was Napoleon Bonaparte?
A: Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military leader who became Emperor.

Q: What is the capital of Switzerland?
A: Bern is the capital of Switzerland, though Zurich is the largest city.

Q: What is the capital of Egypt?
A: Cairo is the capital of Egypt, located on the Nile River.

Q: What is pressure?
A: Pressure is force applied perpendicular to a surface per unit area.

Q: Who was Confucius?
A: Confucius was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings influenced East Asian culture.

Q: What is the capital of Sweden?
A: Stockholm is the capital of Sweden, built on 14 islands.

Q: What is the capital of India?
A: New Delhi is the capital of India, located in northern India.

Q: What is Antarctica?
A: Antarctica is the coldest and driest continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of France?
A: Paris is the capital of France, located on the Seine River.

Q: What is the capital of Ukraine?
A: Kyiv is the capital of Ukraine, located on the Dnieper River.

Q: What is hydrogen?
A: Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1, the lightest element.

Q: What is Saturn?
A: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, famous for its ring system.

Q: Who was Socrates?
A: Socrates was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of Western philosophy.

Q: Who was George Washington?
A: George Washington was the first President of the United States.

Q: What is Mars?
A: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet.

Q: What is the capital of Philippines?
A: Manila is the capital of Philippines, located on Luzon island.

Q: What is the Sun?
A: The Sun is a star at the center of the Solar System, providing light and heat to Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Italy?
A: Rome is the capital of Italy, known as the Eternal City.

Q: What is the capital of Ireland?
A: Dublin is the capital of Ireland, located on the east coast.

Q: Who was Mahatma Gandhi?
A: Mahatma Gandhi was the leader of Indian independence movement.

Q: Who was Winston Churchill?
A: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during World War II.

Q: What is Africa?
A: Africa is the second-largest and second-most populous continent.

Q: What is the capital of South Korea?
A: Seoul is the capital of South Korea, one of the largest metropolitan areas.

Q: Who was Benjamin Franklin?
A: Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath and Founding Father.

Q: What is the capital of Russia?
A: Moscow is the capital of Russia, the largest city in Europe.

Q: What is a molecule?
A: A molecule is a group of atoms bonded together.

Q: What is Europe?
A: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere.

Q: Who was Michelangelo?
A: Michelangelo was an Italian sculptor and painter of the Renaissance.

Q: What is the capital of Vietnam?
A: Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam, located in northern Vietnam.

Q: Who was Wolfgang Mozart?
A: Wolfgang Mozart was an Austrian composer of classical music.

Q: What is Australia?
A: Australia is a country and continent in the Southern Hemisphere.

Q: What is oxygen?
A: Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8, essential for respiration.

Q: Who was Marie Curie?
A: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist who discovered radioactivity.

Q: Who was Aristotle?
A: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist.

Q: What is the capital of Denmark?
A: Copenhagen is the capital of Denmark, located on the islands of Zealand and Amager.

Q: Who was Buddha?
A: Buddha was the founder of Buddhism, born as Siddhartha Gautama.

Q: What is the capital of Poland?
A: Warsaw is the capital of Poland, located on the Vistula River.

Q: What is a cell?
A: A cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

Q: What is the capital of Greece?
A: Athens is the capital of Greece, one of the oldest cities in the world.

Q: What is the capital of Belgium?
A: Brussels is the capital of Belgium, the de facto capital of the European Union.

Q: What is iron?
A: Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26, essential for blood.

Q: Who was Johann Bach?
A: Johann Sebastian Bach was a German composer of the Baroque period.

Q: What is Mount Everest?
A: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth at 8,849 meters.

Q: What is the capital of Indonesia?
A: Jakarta is the capital of Indonesia, located on the island of Java.

Q: What is the capital of China?
A: Beijing is the capital of China, located in northern China.

Q: Who was Vincent van Gogh?
A: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter.

Q: What is South America?
A: South America is a continent in the Western Hemisphere.

Q: What is the Great Wall of China?
A: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications spanning thousands of kilometers.

Q: What is DNA?
A: DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information.

Q: What is the capital of Germany?
A: Berlin is the capital of Germany, the largest city in Germany.

Q: Who was Thomas Jefferson?
A: Thomas Jefferson was the third President and author of the Declaration of Independence.

Q: Who was Muhammad?
A: Muhammad was the founder of Islam and its prophet.

Q: What is magnetism?
A: Magnetism is a force produced by moving electric charges.

Q: What is the capital of Argentina?
A: Buenos Aires is the capital of Argentina, located on the Rio de la Plata.

Q: What is the Eiffel Tower?
A: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower in Paris, France.

Q: What is nitrogen?
A: Nitrogen is a chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7, making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

Q: What is the capital of South Africa?
A: Pretoria is the capital of South Africa, the administrative capital.

Q: What is the Nile?
A: The Nile is the longest river in Africa, flowing through Egypt.

Q: What is the capital of Romania?
A: Bucharest is the capital of Romania, the largest city in Romania.

Q: What is the capital of Hungary?
A: Budapest is the capital of Hungary, formed by uniting Buda and Pest.

Q: What is gravity?
A: Gravity is a force that attracts objects with mass toward each other.

Q: What is light?
A: Light is electromagnetic radiation visible to the human eye.

Q: Who was Alexander Graham Bell?
A: Alexander Graham Bell was the inventor of the telephone.

Q: What is the capital of Mexico?
A: Mexico City is the capital of Mexico, one of the largest cities in the world.

Q: What is sound?
A: Sound is a vibration that travels through air or other media as an audible wave.

Q: What is the Pyramids of Giza?
A: The Pyramids of Giza are ancient Egyptian pyramids near Cairo.

Q: Who was Leonardo da Vinci?
A: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian Renaissance artist and inventor.

Q: What is the capital of Canada?
A: Ottawa is the capital of Canada, located in Ontario.

Q: What is Jupiter?
A: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, a gas giant.

Q: What is the Grand Canyon?
A: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River.

Q: Who was Alexander the Great?
A: Alexander the Great was a Macedonian king who created one of the largest empires.

Q: What is the capital of Austria?
A: Vienna is the capital of Austria, located on the Danube River.

Q: Who was Abraham Lincoln?
A: Abraham Lincoln was the 16th President of the United States.

Q: What is photosynthesis?
A: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy.

Q: What is the Atlantic Ocean?
A: The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the Statue of Liberty?
A: The Statue of Liberty is a copper statue in New York Harbor.

Q: Who was Ludwig Beethoven?
A: Ludwig Beethoven was a German composer who bridged Classical and Romantic eras.

Q: What is electricity?
A: Electricity is the flow of electric charge through a conductor.

Q: What is copper?
A: Copper is a chemical element with symbol Cu and atomic number 29, an excellent conductor.

Q: What is the capital of Czech Republic?
A: Prague is the capital of Czech Republic, known as the City of a Hundred Spires.

Q: Who was Franklin Roosevelt?
A: Franklin D. Roosevelt was the 32nd President of the United States.

Q: Who was Albert Einstein?
A: Albert Einstein was a German-born physicist who developed the theory of relativity.

Q: What is Asia?
A: Asia is the largest and most populous continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Portugal?
A: Lisbon is the capital of Portugal, located on the Atlantic coast.

Q: Who was Pablo Picasso?
A: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter and sculptor who co-founded Cubism.

Q: What is silver?
A: Silver is a chemical element with symbol Ag and atomic number 47, used in jewelry and coins.

Q: What is the Taj Mahal?
A: The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum in Agra, India.

Q: What is the Sahara Desert?
A: The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.

Q: What is gold?
A: Gold is a chemical element with symbol Au and atomic number 79, a precious metal.

Q: What is the capital of Malaysia?
A: Kuala Lumpur is the capital of Malaysia, known for its modern skyline.

Q: Who was Jesus Christ?
A: Jesus Christ was the central figure of Christianity.

Q: What is carbon?
A: Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, the basis of organic chemistry.

Q: Who was William Shakespeare?
A: William Shakespeare was an English playwright and poet.

Q: What is the capital of Turkey?
A: Ankara is the capital of Turkey, though Istanbul is the largest city.

Q: What is respiration?
A: Respiration is the process of exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Q: Who was Galileo Galilei?
A: Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer who supported the heliocentric model.

Q: What is North America?
A: North America is the third-largest continent by area.

Q: What is evolution?
A: Evolution is the process of change in species over generations.

Q: What is the capital of Singapore?
A: Singapore is the capital of Singapore, a city-state in Southeast Asia.

Q: What is temperature?
A: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles.

Q: Who was Nelson Mandela?
A: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and president.

Q: What is the capital of Thailand?
A: Bangkok is the capital of Thailand, known as the City of Angels.

Q: What is the Arctic?
A: The Arctic is the polar region around Earth's North Pole.

Q: What is the capital of Australia?
A: Canberra is the capital of Australia, located between Sydney and Melbourne.

Q: What is the Colosseum?
A: The Colosseum is an ancient Roman amphitheater in Rome.

Q: What is the capital of Netherlands?
A: Amsterdam is the capital of Netherlands, known for its canals.

Q: What is an atom?
A: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.

Q: Who was Thomas Edison?
A: Thomas Edison was an American inventor who created the light bulb.

Q: What is the Moon?
A: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite, orbiting at about 384,400 kilometers.

Q: What is RNA?
A: RNA is ribonucleic acid, essential for protein synthesis.

Q: Who was Isaac Newton?
A: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician and physicist who discovered gravity.

A: Julius Caesar was a Roman general and statesman.

Q: Who was Cleopatra?
A: Cleopatra was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.

A: Henry Ford was an American industrialist who founded Ford Motor Company.

A: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, famous for its ring system.

Q: Who was Socrates?
A: Socrates was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of Western philosophy.

Q: Who was George Washington?
A: George Washington was the first President of the United States.

Q: What is Mars?
A: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet.

Q: What is the capital of Philippines?
A: Manila is the capital of Philippines, located on Luzon island.

Q: What is the Sun?
A: The Sun is a star at the center of the Solar System, providing light and heat to Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Italy?
A: Rome is the capital of Italy, known as the Eternal City.

Q: What is the capital of Ireland?
A: Dublin is the capital of Ireland, located on the east coast.

Q: Who was Mahatma Gandhi?
A: Mahatma Gandhi was the leader of Indian independence movement.

Q: Who was Winston Churchill?
A: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during World War II.

Q: What is Africa?
A: Africa is the second-largest and second-most populous continent.

Q: What is the capital of South Korea?
A: Seoul is the capital of South Korea, one of the largest metropolitan areas.

Q: Who was Benjamin Franklin?
A: Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath and Founding Father.

Q: What is the capital of Russia?
A: Moscow is the capital of Russia, the largest city in Europe.

Q: What is a molecule?
A: A molecule is a group of atoms bonded together.

Q: What is Europe?
A: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere.

Q: Who was Michelangelo?
A: Michelangelo was an Italian sculptor and painter of the Renaissance.

Q: What is the capital of Vietnam?
A: Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam, located in northern Vietnam.

Q: Who was Wolfgang Mozart?
A: Wolfgang Mozart was an Austrian composer of classical music.

Q: What is Australia?
A: Australia is a country and continent in the Southern Hemisphere.

Q: What is oxygen?
A: Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8, essential for respiration.

Q: Who was Marie Curie?
A: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist who discovered radioactivity.

Q: Who was Aristotle?
A: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist.

Q: What is the capital of Denmark?
A: Copenhagen is the capital of Denmark, located on the islands of Zealand and Amager.

Q: Who was Buddha?
A: Buddha was the founder of Buddhism, born as Siddhartha Gautama.

Q: What is the capital of Poland?
A: Warsaw is the capital of Poland, located on the Vistula River.

Q: What is a cell?
A: A cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

Q: What is the capital of Greece?
A: Athens is the capital of Greece, one of the oldest cities in the world.

Q: What is the capital of Belgium?
A: Brussels is the capital of Belgium, the de facto capital of the European Union.

Q: What is iron?
A: Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26, essential for blood.

Q: Who was Johann Bach?
A: Johann Sebastian Bach was a German composer of the Baroque period.

Q: What is Mount Everest?
A: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth at 8,849 meters.

Q: What is the capital of Indonesia?
A: Jakarta is the capital of Indonesia, located on the island of Java.

Q: What is the capital of China?
A: Beijing is the capital of China, located in northern China.

Q: Who was Vincent van Gogh?
A: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter.

Q: What is South America?
A: South America is a continent in the Western Hemisphere.

Q: What is the Great Wall of China?
A: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications spanning thousands of kilometers.

Q: What is DNA?
A: DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information.

Q: What is the capital of Germany?
A: Berlin is the capital of Germany, the largest city in Germany.

Q: Who was Thomas Jefferson?
A: Thomas Jefferson was the third President and author of the Declaration of Independence.

Q: Who was Muhammad?
A: Muhammad was the founder of Islam and its prophet.

Q: What is magnetism?
A: Magnetism is a force produced by moving electric charges.

Q: What is the capital of Argentina?
A: Buenos Aires is the capital of Argentina, located on the Rio de la Plata.

Q: What is the Eiffel Tower?
A: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower in Paris, France.

Q: What is nitrogen?
A: Nitrogen is a chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7, making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

Q: What is the capital of South Africa?
A: Pretoria is the capital of South Africa, the administrative capital.

Q: What is the Nile?
A: The Nile is the longest river in Africa, flowing through Egypt.

Q: What is the capital of Romania?
A: Bucharest is the capital of Romania, the largest city in Romania.

Q: What is the capital of Hungary?
A: Budapest is the capital of Hungary, formed by uniting Buda and Pest.

Q: What is gravity?
A: Gravity is a force that attracts objects with mass toward each other.

Q: What is light?
A: Light is electromagnetic radiation visible to the human eye.

Q: Who was Alexander Graham Bell?
A: Alexander Graham Bell was the inventor of the telephone.

Q: What is the capital of Mexico?
A: Mexico City is the capital of Mexico, one of the largest cities in the world.

Q: What is sound?
A: Sound is a vibration that travels through air or other media as an audible wave.

Q: What is the Pyramids of Giza?
A: The Pyramids of Giza are ancient Egyptian pyramids near Cairo.

Q: Who was Leonardo da Vinci?
A: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian Renaissance artist and inventor.

Q: What is the capital of Canada?
A: Ottawa is the capital of Canada, located in Ontario.

Q: What is Jupiter?
A: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, a gas giant.

Q: What is the Grand Canyon?
A: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River.

Q: Who was Alexander the Great?
A: Alexander the Great was a Macedonian king who created one of the largest empires.

Q: What is the capital of Austria?
A: Vienna is the capital of Austria, located on the Danube River.

Q: Who was Abraham Lincoln?
A: Abraham Lincoln was the 16th President of the United States.

Q: What is photosynthesis?
A: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy.

Q: What is the Atlantic Ocean?
A: The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the Statue of Liberty?
A: The Statue of Liberty is a copper statue in New York Harbor.

Q: Who was Ludwig Beethoven?
A: Ludwig Beethoven was a German composer who bridged Classical and Romantic eras.

Q: What is electricity?
A: Electricity is the flow of electric charge through a conductor.

Q: What is copper?
A: Copper is a chemical element with symbol Cu and atomic number 29, an excellent conductor.

Q: What is the capital of Czech Republic?
A: Prague is the capital of Czech Republic, known as the City of a Hundred Spires.

Q: Who was Franklin Roosevelt?
A: Franklin D. Roosevelt was the 32nd President of the United States.

Q: Who was Albert Einstein?
A: Albert Einstein was a German-born physicist who developed the theory of relativity.

Q: What is Asia?
A: Asia is the largest and most populous continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Portugal?
A: Lisbon is the capital of Portugal, located on the Atlantic coast.

Q: Who was Pablo Picasso?
A: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter and sculptor who co-founded Cubism.

Q: What is silver?
A: Silver is a chemical element with symbol Ag and atomic number 47, used in jewelry and coins.

Q: What is the Taj Mahal?
A: The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum in Agra, India.

Q: What is the Sahara Desert?
A: The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.

Q: What is gold?
A: Gold is a chemical element with symbol Au and atomic number 79, a precious metal.

Q: What is the capital of Malaysia?
A: Kuala Lumpur is the capital of Malaysia, known for its modern skyline.

Q: Who was Jesus Christ?
A: Jesus Christ was the central figure of Christianity.

Q: What is carbon?
A: Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, the basis of organic chemistry.

Q: Who was William Shakespeare?
A: William Shakespeare was an English playwright and poet.

Q: What is the capital of Turkey?
A: Ankara is the capital of Turkey, though Istanbul is the largest city.

Q: What is respiration?
A: Respiration is the process of exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Q: Who was Galileo Galilei?
A: Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer who supported the heliocentric model.

Q: What is North America?
A: North America is the third-largest continent by area.

Q: What is evolution?
A: Evolution is the process of change in species over generations.

Q: What is the capital of Singapore?
A: Singapore is the capital of Singapore, a city-state in Southeast Asia.

Q: What is temperature?
A: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles.

Q: Who was Nelson Mandela?
A: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and president.

Q: What is the capital of Thailand?
A: Bangkok is the capital of Thailand, known as the City of Angels.

Q: What is the Arctic?
A: The Arctic is the polar region around Earth's North Pole.

Q: What is the capital of Australia?
A: Canberra is the capital of Australia, located between Sydney and Melbourne.

Q: What is the Colosseum?
A: The Colosseum is an ancient Roman amphitheater in Rome.

Q: What is the capital of Netherlands?
A: Amsterdam is the capital of Netherlands, known for its canals.

Q: What is an atom?
A: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.

Q: Who was Thomas Edison?
A: Thomas Edison was an American inventor who created the light bulb.

Q: What is the Moon?
A: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite, orbiting at about 384,400 kilometers.

Q: What is RNA?
A: RNA is ribonucleic acid, essential for protein synthesis.

Q: Who was Isaac Newton?
A: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician and physicist who discovered gravity.

Q: Who was Julius Caesar?
A: Julius Caesar was a Roman general and statesman.

Q: Who was Cleopatra?
A: Cleopatra was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.

Q: Who was Henry Ford?
A: Henry Ford was an American industrialist who founded Ford Motor Company.

Q: What is the capital of Norway?
A: Oslo is the capital of Norway, located at the head of a fjord.

Q: What is the capital of Brazil?
A: Brasilia is the capital of Brazil, a planned city built in the 1960s.

Q: Who was Nikola Tesla?
A: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who developed AC electricity.

Q: Who was Plato?
A: Plato was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of the Academy.

Q: What is the Mississippi?
A: The Mississippi is the second-longest river in North America.

Q: Who was Martin Luther King Jr.?
A: Martin Luther King Jr. was an American civil rights leader.

Q: What is the capital of New Zealand?
A: Wellington is the capital of New Zealand, the southernmost capital in the world.

Q: Who was the Wright Brothers?
A: The Wright Brothers were American aviation pioneers who invented the airplane.

Q: What is the capital of Spain?
A: Madrid is the capital of Spain, located in the center of the country.

Q: What is the capital of Japan?
A: Tokyo is the capital of Japan, one of the most populous cities in the world.

Q: What is the Pacific Ocean?
A: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Finland?
A: Helsinki is the capital of Finland, located on the Gulf of Finland.

Q: What is Earth?
A: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known planet with life.

Q: Who was Charles Darwin?
A: Charles Darwin was an English naturalist who developed the theory of evolution.

Q: Who was Queen Victoria?
A: Queen Victoria ruled the United Kingdom from 1837 to 1901.

Q: What is the Amazon?
A: The Amazon is the largest river by volume, flowing through South America.

Q: Who was Queen Elizabeth II?
A: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning British monarch.

Q: What is water?
A: Water is a chemical compound with the formula H2O, essential for all known forms of life.

Q: Who was Napoleon Bonaparte?
A: Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military leader who became Emperor.

Q: What is the capital of Switzerland?
A: Bern is the capital of Switzerland, though Zurich is the largest city.

Q: What is the capital of Egypt?
A: Cairo is the capital of Egypt, located on the Nile River.

Q: What is pressure?
A: Pressure is force applied perpendicular to a surface per unit area.

A: Confucius was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings influenced East Asian culture.

A: Stockholm is the capital of Sweden, built on 14 islands.

A: Athens is the capital of Greece, one of the oldest cities in the world.

Q: What is the capital of Belgium?
A: Brussels is the capital of Belgium, the de facto capital of the European Union.

Q: What is iron?
A: Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26, essential for blood.

Q: Who was Johann Bach?
A: Johann Sebastian Bach was a German composer of the Baroque period.

Q: What is Mount Everest?
A: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth at 8,849 meters.

Q: What is the capital of Indonesia?
A: Jakarta is the capital of Indonesia, located on the island of Java.

Q: What is the capital of China?
A: Beijing is the capital of China, located in northern China.

Q: Who was Vincent van Gogh?
A: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter.

Q: What is South America?
A: South America is a continent in the Western Hemisphere.

Q: What is the Great Wall of China?
A: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications spanning thousands of kilometers.

Q: What is DNA?
A: DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information.

Q: What is the capital of Germany?
A: Berlin is the capital of Germany, the largest city in Germany.

Q: Who was Thomas Jefferson?
A: Thomas Jefferson was the third President and author of the Declaration of Independence.

Q: Who was Muhammad?
A: Muhammad was the founder of Islam and its prophet.

Q: What is magnetism?
A: Magnetism is a force produced by moving electric charges.

Q: What is the capital of Argentina?
A: Buenos Aires is the capital of Argentina, located on the Rio de la Plata.

Q: What is the Eiffel Tower?
A: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower in Paris, France.

Q: What is nitrogen?
A: Nitrogen is a chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7, making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

Q: What is the capital of South Africa?
A: Pretoria is the capital of South Africa, the administrative capital.

Q: What is the Nile?
A: The Nile is the longest river in Africa, flowing through Egypt.

Q: What is the capital of Romania?
A: Bucharest is the capital of Romania, the largest city in Romania.

Q: What is the capital of Hungary?
A: Budapest is the capital of Hungary, formed by uniting Buda and Pest.

Q: What is gravity?
A: Gravity is a force that attracts objects with mass toward each other.

Q: What is light?
A: Light is electromagnetic radiation visible to the human eye.

Q: Who was Alexander Graham Bell?
A: Alexander Graham Bell was the inventor of the telephone.

Q: What is the capital of Mexico?
A: Mexico City is the capital of Mexico, one of the largest cities in the world.

Q: What is sound?
A: Sound is a vibration that travels through air or other media as an audible wave.

Q: What is the Pyramids of Giza?
A: The Pyramids of Giza are ancient Egyptian pyramids near Cairo.

Q: Who was Leonardo da Vinci?
A: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian Renaissance artist and inventor.

Q: What is the capital of Canada?
A: Ottawa is the capital of Canada, located in Ontario.

Q: What is Jupiter?
A: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, a gas giant.

Q: What is the Grand Canyon?
A: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River.

Q: Who was Alexander the Great?
A: Alexander the Great was a Macedonian king who created one of the largest empires.

Q: What is the capital of Austria?
A: Vienna is the capital of Austria, located on the Danube River.

Q: Who was Abraham Lincoln?
A: Abraham Lincoln was the 16th President of the United States.

Q: What is photosynthesis?
A: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy.

Q: What is the Atlantic Ocean?
A: The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the Statue of Liberty?
A: The Statue of Liberty is a copper statue in New York Harbor.

Q: Who was Ludwig Beethoven?
A: Ludwig Beethoven was a German composer who bridged Classical and Romantic eras.

Q: What is electricity?
A: Electricity is the flow of electric charge through a conductor.

Q: What is copper?
A: Copper is a chemical element with symbol Cu and atomic number 29, an excellent conductor.

Q: What is the capital of Czech Republic?
A: Prague is the capital of Czech Republic, known as the City of a Hundred Spires.

Q: Who was Franklin Roosevelt?
A: Franklin D. Roosevelt was the 32nd President of the United States.

Q: Who was Albert Einstein?
A: Albert Einstein was a German-born physicist who developed the theory of relativity.

Q: What is Asia?
A: Asia is the largest and most populous continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Portugal?
A: Lisbon is the capital of Portugal, located on the Atlantic coast.

Q: Who was Pablo Picasso?
A: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter and sculptor who co-founded Cubism.

Q: What is silver?
A: Silver is a chemical element with symbol Ag and atomic number 47, used in jewelry and coins.

Q: What is the Taj Mahal?
A: The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum in Agra, India.

Q: What is the Sahara Desert?
A: The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.

Q: What is gold?
A: Gold is a chemical element with symbol Au and atomic number 79, a precious metal.

Q: What is the capital of Malaysia?
A: Kuala Lumpur is the capital of Malaysia, known for its modern skyline.

Q: Who was Jesus Christ?
A: Jesus Christ was the central figure of Christianity.

Q: What is carbon?
A: Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, the basis of organic chemistry.

Q: Who was William Shakespeare?
A: William Shakespeare was an English playwright and poet.

Q: What is the capital of Turkey?
A: Ankara is the capital of Turkey, though Istanbul is the largest city.

Q: What is respiration?
A: Respiration is the process of exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Q: Who was Galileo Galilei?
A: Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer who supported the heliocentric model.

Q: What is North America?
A: North America is the third-largest continent by area.

Q: What is evolution?
A: Evolution is the process of change in species over generations.

Q: What is the capital of Singapore?
A: Singapore is the capital of Singapore, a city-state in Southeast Asia.

Q: What is temperature?
A: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles.

Q: Who was Nelson Mandela?
A: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and president.

Q: What is the capital of Thailand?
A: Bangkok is the capital of Thailand, known as the City of Angels.

Q: What is the Arctic?
A: The Arctic is the polar region around Earth's North Pole.

Q: What is the capital of Australia?
A: Canberra is the capital of Australia, located between Sydney and Melbourne.

Q: What is the Colosseum?
A: The Colosseum is an ancient Roman amphitheater in Rome.

Q: What is the capital of Netherlands?
A: Amsterdam is the capital of Netherlands, known for its canals.

Q: What is an atom?
A: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.

Q: Who was Thomas Edison?
A: Thomas Edison was an American inventor who created the light bulb.

Q: What is the Moon?
A: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite, orbiting at about 384,400 kilometers.

Q: What is RNA?
A: RNA is ribonucleic acid, essential for protein synthesis.

Q: Who was Isaac Newton?
A: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician and physicist who discovered gravity.

Q: Who was Julius Caesar?
A: Julius Caesar was a Roman general and statesman.

Q: Who was Cleopatra?
A: Cleopatra was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.

Q: Who was Henry Ford?
A: Henry Ford was an American industrialist who founded Ford Motor Company.

Q: What is the capital of Norway?
A: Oslo is the capital of Norway, located at the head of a fjord.

Q: What is the capital of Brazil?
A: Brasilia is the capital of Brazil, a planned city built in the 1960s.

Q: Who was Nikola Tesla?
A: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who developed AC electricity.

Q: Who was Plato?
A: Plato was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of the Academy.

Q: What is the Mississippi?
A: The Mississippi is the second-longest river in North America.

Q: Who was Martin Luther King Jr.?
A: Martin Luther King Jr. was an American civil rights leader.

Q: What is the capital of New Zealand?
A: Wellington is the capital of New Zealand, the southernmost capital in the world.

Q: Who was the Wright Brothers?
A: The Wright Brothers were American aviation pioneers who invented the airplane.

Q: What is the capital of Spain?
A: Madrid is the capital of Spain, located in the center of the country.

Q: What is the capital of Japan?
A: Tokyo is the capital of Japan, one of the most populous cities in the world.

Q: What is the Pacific Ocean?
A: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Finland?
A: Helsinki is the capital of Finland, located on the Gulf of Finland.

Q: What is Earth?
A: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known planet with life.

Q: Who was Charles Darwin?
A: Charles Darwin was an English naturalist who developed the theory of evolution.

Q: Who was Queen Victoria?
A: Queen Victoria ruled the United Kingdom from 1837 to 1901.

Q: What is the Amazon?
A: The Amazon is the largest river by volume, flowing through South America.

Q: Who was Queen Elizabeth II?
A: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning British monarch.

Q: What is water?
A: Water is a chemical compound with the formula H2O, essential for all known forms of life.

Q: Who was Napoleon Bonaparte?
A: Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military leader who became Emperor.

Q: What is the capital of Switzerland?
A: Bern is the capital of Switzerland, though Zurich is the largest city.

Q: What is the capital of Egypt?
A: Cairo is the capital of Egypt, located on the Nile River.

Q: What is pressure?
A: Pressure is force applied perpendicular to a surface per unit area.

Q: Who was Confucius?
A: Confucius was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings influenced East Asian culture.

Q: What is the capital of Sweden?
A: Stockholm is the capital of Sweden, built on 14 islands.

Q: What is the capital of India?
A: New Delhi is the capital of India, located in northern India.

Q: What is Antarctica?
A: Antarctica is the coldest and driest continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of France?
A: Paris is the capital of France, located on the Seine River.

Q: What is the capital of Ukraine?
A: Kyiv is the capital of Ukraine, located on the Dnieper River.

Q: What is hydrogen?
A: Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1, the lightest element.

Q: What is Saturn?
A: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, famous for its ring system.

Q: Who was Socrates?
A: Socrates was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of Western philosophy.

Q: Who was George Washington?
A: George Washington was the first President of the United States.

Q: What is Mars?
A: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet.

Q: What is the capital of Philippines?
A: Manila is the capital of Philippines, located on Luzon island.

Q: What is the Sun?
A: The Sun is a star at the center of the Solar System, providing light and heat to Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Italy?
A: Rome is the capital of Italy, known as the Eternal City.

Q: What is the capital of Ireland?
A: Dublin is the capital of Ireland, located on the east coast.

Q: Who was Mahatma Gandhi?
A: Mahatma Gandhi was the leader of Indian independence movement.

Q: Who was Winston Churchill?
A: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during World War II.

Q: What is Africa?
A: Africa is the second-largest and second-most populous continent.

A: Seoul is the capital of South Korea, one of the largest metropolitan areas.

A: Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath and Founding Father.

A: Moscow is the capital of Russia, the largest city in Europe.

A: A molecule is a group of atoms bonded together.

A: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere.

A: Michelangelo was an Italian sculptor and painter of the Renaissance.

Q: What is the capital of Vietnam?
A: Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam, located in northern Vietnam.

A: Wolfgang Mozart was an Austrian composer of classical music.

Q: What is Australia?
A: Australia is a country and continent in the Southern Hemisphere.

A: Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8, essential for respiration.

A: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist who discovered radioactivity.

A: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist.

Q: What is the Pyramids of Giza?
A: The Pyramids of Giza are ancient Egyptian pyramids near Cairo.

Q: Who was Leonardo da Vinci?
A: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian Renaissance artist and inventor.

Q: What is the capital of Canada?
A: Ottawa is the capital of Canada, located in Ontario.

Q: What is Jupiter?
A: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System, a gas giant.

Q: What is the Grand Canyon?
A: The Grand Canyon is a steep-sided canyon carved by the Colorado River.

Q: Who was Alexander the Great?
A: Alexander the Great was a Macedonian king who created one of the largest empires.

Q: What is the capital of Austria?
A: Vienna is the capital of Austria, located on the Danube River.

Q: Who was Abraham Lincoln?
A: Abraham Lincoln was the 16th President of the United States.

Q: What is photosynthesis?
A: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy.

Q: What is the Atlantic Ocean?
A: The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the Statue of Liberty?
A: The Statue of Liberty is a copper statue in New York Harbor.

Q: Who was Ludwig Beethoven?
A: Ludwig Beethoven was a German composer who bridged Classical and Romantic eras.

Q: What is electricity?
A: Electricity is the flow of electric charge through a conductor.

Q: What is copper?
A: Copper is a chemical element with symbol Cu and atomic number 29, an excellent conductor.

Q: What is the capital of Czech Republic?
A: Prague is the capital of Czech Republic, known as the City of a Hundred Spires.

Q: Who was Franklin Roosevelt?
A: Franklin D. Roosevelt was the 32nd President of the United States.

Q: Who was Albert Einstein?
A: Albert Einstein was a German-born physicist who developed the theory of relativity.

Q: What is Asia?
A: Asia is the largest and most populous continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Portugal?
A: Lisbon is the capital of Portugal, located on the Atlantic coast.

Q: Who was Pablo Picasso?
A: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter and sculptor who co-founded Cubism.

Q: What is silver?
A: Silver is a chemical element with symbol Ag and atomic number 47, used in jewelry and coins.

Q: What is the Taj Mahal?
A: The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum in Agra, India.

Q: What is the Sahara Desert?
A: The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.

Q: What is gold?
A: Gold is a chemical element with symbol Au and atomic number 79, a precious metal.

Q: What is the capital of Malaysia?
A: Kuala Lumpur is the capital of Malaysia, known for its modern skyline.

Q: Who was Jesus Christ?
A: Jesus Christ was the central figure of Christianity.

Q: What is carbon?
A: Carbon is a chemical element with symbol C and atomic number 6, the basis of organic chemistry.

Q: Who was William Shakespeare?
A: William Shakespeare was an English playwright and poet.

Q: What is the capital of Turkey?
A: Ankara is the capital of Turkey, though Istanbul is the largest city.

Q: What is respiration?
A: Respiration is the process of exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Q: Who was Galileo Galilei?
A: Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer who supported the heliocentric model.

Q: What is North America?
A: North America is the third-largest continent by area.

Q: What is evolution?
A: Evolution is the process of change in species over generations.

Q: What is the capital of Singapore?
A: Singapore is the capital of Singapore, a city-state in Southeast Asia.

Q: What is temperature?
A: Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles.

Q: Who was Nelson Mandela?
A: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and president.

Q: What is the capital of Thailand?
A: Bangkok is the capital of Thailand, known as the City of Angels.

Q: What is the Arctic?
A: The Arctic is the polar region around Earth's North Pole.

Q: What is the capital of Australia?
A: Canberra is the capital of Australia, located between Sydney and Melbourne.

Q: What is the Colosseum?
A: The Colosseum is an ancient Roman amphitheater in Rome.

Q: What is the capital of Netherlands?
A: Amsterdam is the capital of Netherlands, known for its canals.

Q: What is an atom?
A: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.

Q: Who was Thomas Edison?
A: Thomas Edison was an American inventor who created the light bulb.

Q: What is the Moon?
A: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite, orbiting at about 384,400 kilometers.

Q: What is RNA?
A: RNA is ribonucleic acid, essential for protein synthesis.

Q: Who was Isaac Newton?
A: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician and physicist who discovered gravity.

Q: Who was Julius Caesar?
A: Julius Caesar was a Roman general and statesman.

Q: Who was Cleopatra?
A: Cleopatra was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.

Q: Who was Henry Ford?
A: Henry Ford was an American industrialist who founded Ford Motor Company.

Q: What is the capital of Norway?
A: Oslo is the capital of Norway, located at the head of a fjord.

Q: What is the capital of Brazil?
A: Brasilia is the capital of Brazil, a planned city built in the 1960s.

Q: Who was Nikola Tesla?
A: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who developed AC electricity.

Q: Who was Plato?
A: Plato was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of the Academy.

Q: What is the Mississippi?
A: The Mississippi is the second-longest river in North America.

Q: Who was Martin Luther King Jr.?
A: Martin Luther King Jr. was an American civil rights leader.

Q: What is the capital of New Zealand?
A: Wellington is the capital of New Zealand, the southernmost capital in the world.

Q: Who was the Wright Brothers?
A: The Wright Brothers were American aviation pioneers who invented the airplane.

Q: What is the capital of Spain?
A: Madrid is the capital of Spain, located in the center of the country.

Q: What is the capital of Japan?
A: Tokyo is the capital of Japan, one of the most populous cities in the world.

Q: What is the Pacific Ocean?
A: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Finland?
A: Helsinki is the capital of Finland, located on the Gulf of Finland.

Q: What is Earth?
A: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known planet with life.

Q: Who was Charles Darwin?
A: Charles Darwin was an English naturalist who developed the theory of evolution.

Q: Who was Queen Victoria?
A: Queen Victoria ruled the United Kingdom from 1837 to 1901.

Q: What is the Amazon?
A: The Amazon is the largest river by volume, flowing through South America.

Q: Who was Queen Elizabeth II?
A: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-reigning British monarch.

Q: What is water?
A: Water is a chemical compound with the formula H2O, essential for all known forms of life.

Q: Who was Napoleon Bonaparte?
A: Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military leader who became Emperor.

Q: What is the capital of Switzerland?
A: Bern is the capital of Switzerland, though Zurich is the largest city.

Q: What is the capital of Egypt?
A: Cairo is the capital of Egypt, located on the Nile River.

Q: What is pressure?
A: Pressure is force applied perpendicular to a surface per unit area.

Q: Who was Confucius?
A: Confucius was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings influenced East Asian culture.

Q: What is the capital of Sweden?
A: Stockholm is the capital of Sweden, built on 14 islands.

Q: What is the capital of India?
A: New Delhi is the capital of India, located in northern India.

Q: What is Antarctica?
A: Antarctica is the coldest and driest continent on Earth.

Q: What is the capital of France?
A: Paris is the capital of France, located on the Seine River.

Q: What is the capital of Ukraine?
A: Kyiv is the capital of Ukraine, located on the Dnieper River.

Q: What is hydrogen?
A: Hydrogen is a chemical element with symbol H and atomic number 1, the lightest element.

Q: What is Saturn?
A: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, famous for its ring system.

Q: Who was Socrates?
A: Socrates was an ancient Greek philosopher and founder of Western philosophy.

Q: Who was George Washington?
A: George Washington was the first President of the United States.

Q: What is Mars?
A: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, known as the Red Planet.

Q: What is the capital of Philippines?
A: Manila is the capital of Philippines, located on Luzon island.

Q: What is the Sun?
A: The Sun is a star at the center of the Solar System, providing light and heat to Earth.

Q: What is the capital of Italy?
A: Rome is the capital of Italy, known as the Eternal City.

Q: What is the capital of Ireland?
A: Dublin is the capital of Ireland, located on the east coast.

Q: Who was Mahatma Gandhi?
A: Mahatma Gandhi was the leader of Indian independence movement.

Q: Who was Winston Churchill?
A: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during World War II.

Q: What is Africa?
A: Africa is the second-largest and second-most populous continent.

Q: What is the capital of South Korea?
A: Seoul is the capital of South Korea, one of the largest metropolitan areas.

Q: Who was Benjamin Franklin?
A: Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath and Founding Father.

Q: What is the capital of Russia?
A: Moscow is the capital of Russia, the largest city in Europe.

Q: What is a molecule?
A: A molecule is a group of atoms bonded together.

Q: What is Europe?
A: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere.

Q: Who was Michelangelo?
A: Michelangelo was an Italian sculptor and painter of the Renaissance.

Q: What is the capital of Vietnam?
A: Hanoi is the capital of Vietnam, located in northern Vietnam.

Q: Who was Wolfgang Mozart?
A: Wolfgang Mozart was an Austrian composer of classical music.

Q: What is Australia?
A: Australia is a country and continent in the Southern Hemisphere.

Q: What is oxygen?
A: Oxygen is a chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8, essential for respiration.

Q: Who was Marie Curie?
A: Marie Curie was a Polish-French physicist who discovered radioactivity.

Q: Who was Aristotle?
A: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist.

Q: What is the capital of Denmark?
A: Copenhagen is the capital of Denmark, located on the islands of Zealand and Amager.

Q: Who was Buddha?
A: Buddha was the founder of Buddhism, born as Siddhartha Gautama.

Q: What is the capital of Poland?
A: Warsaw is the capital of Poland, located on the Vistula River.

Q: What is a cell?
A: A cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

Q: What is the capital of Greece?
A: Athens is the capital of Greece, one of the oldest cities in the world.

Q: What is the capital of Belgium?
A: Brussels is the capital of Belgium, the de facto capital of the European Union.

Q: What is iron?
A: Iron is a chemical element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26, essential for blood.

Q: Who was Johann Bach?
A: Johann Sebastian Bach was a German composer of the Baroque period.

Q: What is Mount Everest?
A: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth at 8,849 meters.

Q: What is the capital of Indonesia?
A: Jakarta is the capital of Indonesia, located on the island of Java.

Q: What is the capital of China?
A: Beijing is the capital of China, located in northern China.

Q: Who was Vincent van Gogh?
A: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter.

Q: What is South America?
A: South America is a continent in the Western Hemisphere.

Q: What is the Great Wall of China?
A: The Great Wall of China is a series of fortifications spanning thousands of kilometers.

Q: What is DNA?
A: DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that carries genetic information.

Q: What is the capital of Germany?
A: Berlin is the capital of Germany, the largest city in Germany.

Q: Who was Thomas Jefferson?
A: Thomas Jefferson was the third President and author of the Declaration of Independence.

Q: Who was Muhammad?
A: Muhammad was the founder of Islam and its prophet.

Q: What is magnetism?
A: Magnetism is a force produced by moving electric charges.

Q: What is the capital of Argentina?
A: Buenos Aires is the capital of Argentina, located on the Rio de la Plata.

Q: What is the Eiffel Tower?
A: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought-iron lattice tower in Paris, France.

Q: What is nitrogen?
A: Nitrogen is a chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7, making up 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

Q: What is the capital of South Africa?
A: Pretoria is the capital of South Africa, the administrative capital.

Q: What is the Nile?
A: The Nile is the longest river in Africa, flowing through Egypt.

Q: What is the capital of Romania?
A: Bucharest is the capital of Romania, the largest city in Romania.

Q: What is the capital of Hungary?
A: Budapest is the capital of Hungary, formed by uniting Buda and Pest.

Q: What is gravity?
A: Gravity is a force that attracts objects with mass toward each other.

A: Light is electromagnetic radiation visible to the human eye.

A: Alexander Graham Bell was the inventor of the telephone.
